titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I was entirely smoked out of my room this day, in which it was impossible to keep a fire— To all the purposes of my proper occupation this day like all its predecessors since my return, and like the days to come, I know not for what length of time, is lost— I called on Dr: Welsh, requesting him to attend Mrs: Adams who is extremely ill— Towards Evening I walk’d with George, and called at Mr: Shaw’s Office— There I received a Note requesting my attendance this Evening at Concert Hall, on Federal Business— I first returned home, and between 8 and 9 in the Evening went to Whitcomb’s Hall, where were assembled about one hundred persons, preparing for the next week’s Election— Several Resolutions were pass’d— But some objection arising to those which had been reported, by a Committee, they were recommitted for revisal, with the addition of three new members— There were two before— I was immediately placed upon the additional Committee. The Resolutions being revised and amended were unanimously agreed to— A Motion then was made that they should be signed by the Moderator and Secretary of the meeting, and published in the newspapers, the remainder of the week— Mr: S. Codman, the Moderator objected to signing them, as being one of the minority of the Legislature, whose conduct was approved— To obviate this difficulty he was excused from further presiding, and a new Moderator chosen—viz—myself— The motions for the signing and publishing the Resolutions then pass’d, and the meeting was adjourned to Sunday Evening— It was about 10 at Night before I got home—

2. I saw Mr: I. P. Davis this day, and had some further conversation with him respecting his houses, but came to no final arrangement with him— Sent John to school at Mrs: Parker’s, with his brother George. I read but little, and wrote nothing. The Season continues as severe as we have it generally at Washington in January— This Evening we had another fall of Snow with violent gale;—and I find that my house at such times both smokes and leaks to such a degree that some of the chambers become entirely uninhabitable.— Mrs: Adams continues very ill, confined to her chamber.

div.p: 3. I walk’d up to Cambridge this morning half-leg deep in mud; and in the face of a violent gale— I went into the Library, and sent for the freshman to ring the bell for my lecture; but he was not to be found— After waiting some time I sent again, without being more successful; I then went to Dr: Waterhouse’s where I found the freshman had been for me; but it was now too late to deliver the lecture— I remained at Dr: W’s untill 2. and then attended at the Declamation— After this I returned to Boston in the Stage— The Corporation were sitting this day, respecting some disorders which have recently occurr’d among the students; they sent me an invitation to dinner, but I was engaged to dine in Boston with Mr: Gardner Greene— I went there accordingly with Caroline, Mrs: Adams being still confined to her chamber— The Company at Mr: Green’s was of about twenty, Ladies and Gentlemen— Among the rest was Mrs. Belcher an old acquaintance of mine; whom I did not immediately recognize— Coll: Sheaff also was there— We came home about 8 this Evening.

4. We had a load of furniture come in this morning from Quincy, and were employed the whole day in unpacking, and getting it into the house— I was unable to go out— Mr: Shaw called here this afternoon, and mentioned to me that the Corporation had yesterday drawn up a sort of confession which they required that the Students should sign, on pain of expulsion.— And this day the Students had met, and all agreed not to sign it; but to leave the College— They have untill next Saturday however to make their final determination— I received a written invitation to attend the federal meeting to-morrow Evening; and a request to appear as a Speaker; I shall not speak, but will attend the meeting.

5. I took George to meeting with me this day, and heard Mr: Emerson all the afternoon—and Dr: Lathrop, for him in the morning— His Sermon was on the uses of Affliction—from the textit is good for me that I have been afflicted—that I might learn thy Statutes— I had once heard from the same place an excellent Sermon from that text, delivered by Mr Brown the Scotchman.— But I was much pleased with this of Mr: Emerson; which was occasional, to himself— On the Death of
of his Sister, Mrs: Farnham, of Newbury-Port— Mr: Dexter called upon me this afternoon. Harriet Welsh was also here— I attended the federal meeting at Faneuil-Hall this Evening— The Hall was nearly as full as it could hold. Mr: Quincy was speaking when I went in— Mr: Otis and Mr: Gore succeeded him— But there was no diversity of opinion— The vote was put for supporting Mr: Strong as Governor, at the Election to morrow, and Mr: Robbins at Lt: Govr: with the last year’s list of Senators— They were all unanimously carried— Walking home with Mr: Dexter, I was remarking, upon the questionable nature of this party-organization, and its tendency under our Constitution— It is perhaps unavoidable; but it is not altogether reconcileable to the freedom of the elective principle.

6. I had been placed at the list of one hundred and twenty distributors of votes; and it was agreed to meet this morning at the Marine Insurance Office, where they were to be prepared, as we found them— The poll opened at 9. O’Clock, and closed at two, afternoon— The number of votes upwards of 3000 for Mr: Strong; and of 2000 for Mr: Sullivan, a greater number on both sides than were ever before given—by nearly one thousand votes in the whole— While on the ground I conversed with Judge Davis and Mr: Jackson, members of the College Corporation— With Mr: Whitman, Mr: Morse, and Mr: English, and Mr: Parkman, who have sons at College; endeavouring to produce a settlement of the difficulties between the Government of College, and the Students— I also conversed with Mr: Parkman’s Son, and endeavoured to persuade him to take the only course proper in this case; a compliance with the requisitions of the Corporation— I spent the afternoon and Evening at home; but it was engrossed in arrangements of furniture; for we are yet far from being settled in the house, nor can I at all pursue my regular course of studies—

7. My Sister Smith and Louisa came into Town this morning, and returned at Night— I call’d on the Schoolmaster Mr: Webb, and agreed to send my George to him next Monday; to begin to learn to write— To attend one hour daily—from 5 to 6. in the afternoon— I dined at Mr: B. Greene’s; with a Company of Gentlemen principally; and spent the Evening, at Mr: Parkman’s— I am still under the doom of idleness.

8. I Dined at Mr: John Amory’s; with Genl: Cobb, Mr: T. Amory, and Mr: Preble— Morning, and Evening at home— I wrote a few lines, but we continue still in so great disorder that I am unable to do any thing systematically. Mrs: Adams rode out this morning, but continues very ill, with an inveterate and almost incessant cough.

9. Fast-Day— Mr: Hall called upon me this morning. I went with my children in the morning, and with them and Caroline afternoon, and heard Mr: Ware and Mr: Emerson— John Smith came into town from Quincy this day— Mrs: Smith, and her daughters were here this afternoon. She is very anxious on account of her Son who is at College, and has taken part with the other students in a formal and concerted resistance against the Government and Corporation

10. I went to Cambridge this morning, and took John Smith with me— Called at William Smith’s chamber, but he was gone out of town— Went to Dr: Waterhouse’s; he shewed me a letter he had prepared to send to President Webber, proposing that a recess of a fortnight should be directed by the College Government, to give the Students time to reflect— He asked my opinion with respect to this proposition, which I freely gave him, against it— At 10. I gave my 13th: lecture, which was thinly attended. Afterwards I called at the President’s and at Mr: Ware’s— At 2 I attended the Declamation— Not half the scholars were there; only four declaimed; and that very badly— A Committee of twelve Gentlemen deputed from the Parents and Guardians of the Students from Boston and the vicinity, were at Cambridge, endeavouring to prevail upon them to comply with the requisitions of the Corporation; but without success— They were still there, when I came away— I walked home— John Smith had returned with the Chaise immediately after the Lecture in the Morning— My wood arrived this day from Quincy.

11. I dined, with a company of about 25 Gentlemen at Mr: John Gore’s— Mrs: Gore and Mrs: Babcock were the only Ladies present— The principal topic of conversation related to the proceedings of the students at Harvard College, who have now published a pamphlet in their own vindication— About one third of them however this day signed the paper required by the corporation.

12— Heard Mr: Channing the whole day; on the duties of children to their parents— John Smith went to Quincy this morning, and returned in the Evening.— I pass’d the greater part of the Evening at Mr: Dexter’s. Read Tillotson’s Sermons 90 and 91. on covetousness— My Eldest son, George is this day six years old— George 3. f. 8. 1/2 i.— John. 3. f.

13. There was a meeting of the College-Corporation this day at Cambridge, at which they took some further measures respecting the Students, a majority of whom are still in resistance against the authority of the Government— I was much of this day about the town, making arrangements for procuring a convenient chamber to study and write in— This afternoon I took George to writing school, at Mr: Webb’s.— He is to go there, an hour every day for one Quarter, and continue still, at Mrs: Parker’s.— Evening at home.

14. My brother and his wife came in to Boston— He dined with us; as did also Mr: Townsend, whom I met in the Street, and who came from Dedham this morning— I am still very much engaged in my family arrangements, and find no time for writing— Very little for reading— This mode of life is repugnant to my inclinations, but from a wavering, dilatory propensity in my disposition, continues much too long— I doubt indeed whether I shall be able at all to study, here as I have done both at Washington, and at Cambridge.

15. I was again engaged the whole day in preparing my chamber for a study and library— Four weeks already have elapsed since I reached home, and came in to this house; and I have yet done nothing— With some allowances for Circumstances, I am still far from having any self-approbation to bestow— I this Evening met the Wednesday Evening’s club at Judge Dawes’s. A large proportion of the Cambridge students have left the Colleges, and are returning home.

16. At length I am able for the first time to take my chamber for use, and began writing and reading in it. I did however but little, nor is it yet in a state of full preparation— I saw Mr: I. P. Davis this day at noon, and agreed with him, to take both his houses.— We have now only to execute the deeds and make arrangements for the payment; in doing which I expect some embarrassment; though I believe this a safe and prudent purchase— Dr: and Mrs: Waterhouse called to see us this afternoon— I spent the Evening with Chief-Justice Parsons— Judge Davis was there with him— Mr: Parsons told me that one of his ancestors was the inventor of the kind of vessel called a Schooner.— The Overseers of the College have this day had a meeting, and unanimously approved the proceedings of the Corporation respecting the refractory Students.

div.p: 17. I spent this day in my chamber, and employed it in writing for my lectures— I should have attended at Cambridge; but so few of the students remain there, that I have concluded not to go there untill the College gets into a more settled State— I walk’d with my children this afternoon— Mrs: Adams continues very unwell.

18. This day was again entirely lost to my studies— The necessary occupations of my family having taken up my whole time. This afternoon I walk’d with Mrs: Adams, and afterwards with my children— In the Evening J. Smith walk’d out to Quincy. Mr. I. P. Davis gave me the deed of his place bounding upon mine, which he has agreed to sell me— I met Mr: Hedge the tutor, who informed me that the College was nearly broken up— Not more than forty of the students remaining there

19. Went out to Quincy this morning with Mrs: Adams; and we took John with us in the Chaise— We returned in the Evening— I heard there, both parts of the day, a young man named Norton, who has just commenced Preacher— He has talents; but a very bad enunciation— John was very unwell the whole day, and after we came home this Evening had a very high fever— Mrs: Adams’s cough also continues unabated— Mr: and Mrs: Quincy were here part of the Evening— Caroline spent it at Dr: Welsh’s— The warm weather is beginning; and the Common before us, since yesterday morning has assumed its first verdure.

20. I was employed all the morning in endeavouring to engage a man-servant instead of the man we have hitherto had; with him I had so much reason to be dissatisfied that I this Evening dismiss’d him: even without waiting untill I could get another— Mrs: Adams and John continue quite ill— My family cares still absorb all my time; and much to my distress.

21. We engaged two new Servants—Theodore French, as Man-Servant, and Sally Hayden, a girl of about thirteen, who is to live untill eighteen with Mrs: Adams, if they should mutually suit— I attended an Auction of furniture at the late Mr: Hill’s, but without obtaining the Articles I wanted— This Evening I called with Caroline upon Mr: & Mrs: Quincy, for a couple of hours— I was unable to write still this day as hitherto.

22 I was employed all the morning upon household affairs— Saw Mr: I. P. Davis, and made some further arrangements with him, respecting the purchases I propose making of him— Came to no definitive settlement— Dr: Welsh’s family were here at tea, and to spend the Evening.— I was afterwards an hour at the Club at Dr: Dexter’s— On returning home I found Mrs: Adams very ill— Her cough yields to nothing hitherto.

23. Mrs: Adams had a very bad Night, and I was great part of it up.— I finished my bargain with I. P. Davis for the house adjoining mine in Nassau-Street— Paid him part of the money, and gave him my notes for the remainder— My brother and John Smith came into town this afternoon; but my brother immediately returned. Spent the Evening with Caroline, at Mr: S. A. Otis’s— His son, with Lady and daughter were there— Mrs: Sumner, Mrs: Dexter & some other company.— Music.

div.p: 24. John Smith walk’d up with me this morning to Cambridge. At 10. I read my fourteenth lecture.— There were not more than twenty Students who attended—only two or three of the Senior Class.— I pass’d a couple of hour afterwards in the library, and read part of a Dissertation upon Eloquence by Leland—a refutation of some of Warburton’s paradoxes— I afterwards called on President Webber, who informed me of the present State of the College— Twenty-seven of the Students have been finally dismissed; about six or eight remain liable to the same decision— Upwards of one hundred have complied with the requisition of the Corporation, and two have left College, one before, and the other after signing the paper prescribed. I called also at Mr: J. Greenleaf’s, and made him a proposition at the request of Mr: J. Gardner, to take his house at Milton and his children: but found as I had expected, that it would not suit him— After some conversation with Dr: Waterhouse, at 2. I attended the Declamation; only two speakers appeared— But several came with the minutes of their pieces for the next week— The regent’s freshman applied to me for liberty to attend my lectures; but I could not give it— I walk’d home immediately after the Declamation— We dined at 4. O’Clock— In the Evening, I attended by invitation the Society for the Study of natural philosophy, and heard a lecture from Dr Gorham, upon Mineralogy—

25. Mr: Quincy called upon me this morning, and proposed some accommodation to me, respecting the engagements I am forming with Mr: Davis; but upon such terms, as I found would not suit Davis— I called at the Office of the Register of Deeds, and left for record there, that which I have already taken— At the same time, I examined the titles of the Estate in Hancock Street: Beacon Hill; which I traced to the year 1743.— I had some further conversation with Mr: Davis; but without coming to a conclusion, with regard to the place on Fort-Hill.— Dined at Dr: Warren’s, with the Trustees of the Agricultural Society. My father was there— He came in to town with Louisa and Caroline Smith— They returned in the Evening to Quincy, and John Smith with them.

26. I went this morning with Mr: Quincy to Mr: Kirkland’s; where I heard Mr: Farrar, the new Mathematical Professor at the College— In the afternoon I went with Caroline and George to hear Mr: Emerson— John Smith, and Mrs: T. B. Adams came into town this afternoon— Mrs: Adams and her brother were here in the Evening— Mr: Shaw was also here. I wrote a little, on my lecture, and believe that with Perseverance and Resolution I might still make some progress.

27. Dexter came in from Quincy this morning with a load of furniture— Mrs: T. B. Adams dined and passed the day with us. But neither her brother, nor Mr: Shaw came, though engaged— I commenced writing this morning, more assiduously than hitherto; but was diverted from my business part of the day, by a sale of furniture at Auction which I attended—

28. I wrote this day less than yesterday— Took I. P. Davis’s deed of the House in Hancock-Street which he had sold me, and paid him, one half by my note, and one half cash, for which I gave my note to Mr: Quincy— I dined with Mr. Boylston at Jamaica-Plains— Mr: Hallowell, Mr: Jos: Russell, Mr: Ritchie, and Mr: Haliburton were there— Walking
home I was overtaken by Mr: John Prince, and took a seat with him in his chair— After returning home, I walk’d alone in the Mall

29. Dined with a Company of about twenty Gentlemen, at Mr: Craigie’s in Cambridge— I took a Carriage, with Mr: Hallowell, Mr: Allen the Sheriff, Mr: Hall and Mr: Quincy.— Instead of Hall, Mr: I. P. Davis came home with us— We returned to Boston early in the Evening.

30. Mr: Hall, called here this forenoon, and Caroline went with him to visit Mrs: Parker his Sister— This afternoon I called for about half an hour at Mr: Shaw’s Office— The remainder of the day I spent at home, and wrote, as much as I could— But I was not very well and effected but little.

Day. My course of life continues irregular— The sickness in my family which has been unremitted from the day of my arrival in Boston to this, and the confusion of removals and domestic arrangements have kept me in such constant disorder, that the distribution and employment of my time is not the same, for any two days in succession— Excepting one day when the College was in a manner broken up, I have uniformly attended on Fridays at Cambridge; but my preparatory studies for future lectures have been interrupted or neglected more than I had apprehended— With my other avocations I have been taken up sometime with certain new dispositions of my Estate; which however I hope are now nearly concluded for the present. During great part of the Month I have had no place for retirement, where I could study, and I am not yet in that state of order which is essential to the pursuit of objects like those before me— I have constantly attended to George’s French lessons, in which he improves slowly— May I be enabled to give a better account of the next Month.
